I am sorry but he is not available at the moment.
call back
I will call back later this afternoon.
leave a message
Leave a message and I'll call you back.
text message
Send me a text message later and I will meet you.
hang up
I am sorry, I have to hang up because there is someone at the door.
be on hold
How annoying! I have been on hold for 20 minutes.
cut off
The phone cut off in mid conversation because I have no signal.
low battery
My phone has low battery
the financial crisis
The financial crisis has affected many European countries.
economic slowdown
The economic slowdown is having a huge effect on house prices.
inflation
Inflation is a rise in the general level of prices of goods and services in an economy.
loan
I would like to take out a loan to buy a car please.
make redundant
The business made five people redundant last month.
mortgage
They're going to give us the mortgage.
debt
Many people have debts which can seriously affect their financial situation.
investment bank
Governments have had to bail out many investment banks.
interest rate
Interest rates on car loans have risen recently.
I'd like to take out a mortgage.
Discussing issues that affect us today
On the telephone
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
I'm trying to get through to the bank but I've been [k]on hold[/k] for ages.
This happened to me last week, and then when I finally got through, the person I needed was [k]not available[/k].
Oh no, how annoying! The problem is I have [k]low battery[/k].
Is there an option to [k]leave a message[/k]? Maybe someone could [k]call back[/k] when they're less busy?
I didn't get that option at the beginning I don't think. Maybe I should just send them an email and ask them to call me themselves.
I agree. What is it that you want to talk to them about anyway?
I got a [k]text message[/k] from them saying that I was eligible to open a new savings account.
Oh really? That might help you save up for that new bike that you want.
Carl
Diana
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
The financial crisis
[k]The financial crisis[/k] has been making the headlines again recently. What do you think is going to happen?
I'm really not sure, to be honest. Supposedly, the rate of [k]inflation[/k] is steady but unemployment has gone up again. How are things where you work?
Well, a few people were [k]made redundant[/k] last month, so my workload's nearly doubled.
I don't know how you cope, John! Although since my husband, Mark, lost his job we've also been struggling to pay the [k]mortgage[/k].
How's he been coping? It must be very stressful to lose your job.
Yes, he's not very well really. He's been thinking of setting up his own business, but getting a [k]loan[/k] from the bank these days is impossible.
Yes and if they do give you one, the [k]interest rates[/k] are really high!
I just hope things start getting better soon. I don't know what we'll do otherwise.
John
Maria
What do you think caused the global financial crisis? How can we prevent further financial crises?
I think the financial crisis was caused by banks giving too many bad loans to people. To prevent another one, banks should be more careful about who they give mortgages to.
Grammar: Past perfect continuous
The sentence talks about more than one past event.
We'd been working hard all day and needed a cup of tea.
True or false?
I bought all the food from the local shop on the corner of my street.
They had been waiting in traffic for 6 hours and were exhausted.
We use the Past Perfect Continuous tense to talk about events leading up to a time or event in the past. It is used to look backwards from a time in the past.
We'd been working hard all day and needed a cup of tea.
The sentence focuses on the length of the action.
She'd been waiting for over an hour and was freezing cold.
We'd already started dinner when they arrived.
The editor had been working at the paper for 30 years when he retired.
We often use the Past Perfect Continuous tense to focus on the length of the action. We can use time expressions with for and since:
She'd been waiting for three hours / for ages / since that morning / since 7 a.m.
[k]We had[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]surfing[/k] [k]for three hours[/k] [k]by the time it got dark.[/k]
[k]I[/k] [k]hadn't[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]practising[/k] [k]enough[/k] [k]and I failed the test.[/k]
[k]Had[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]waiting[/k] [k]for long[/k] [k]when she arrived?[/k]
To form the Past Perfect Continuous we use had + been + -ing form of the verb:
I had been waiting... / I'd been waiting...
For negative sentences we add 'not' after 'had':
I hadn't been waiting...
For questions we put the subject after 'had':
Had you been waiting...?
The plumber [k]had been trying[/k] to fix the boiler all day.
had tried
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I [k]had just bought[/k] the car and I crashed it into a wall.
had just been buying
He [k]had been making[/k] food all day and kitchen was a mess.
had made
She had been expecting him [k]for[/k] over an hour.
since
The cake had been sitting in the kitchen all day, so [k]I ate[/k] it.
had eaten
Past Perfect Continuous - not drive
I [k]hadn't been driving|had not been driving[/k] for long but I was tired and decided to stop.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Past Perfect Continuous - broadcast
The radio station [k]had been broadcasting[/k] since the war.
Past Perfect Continuous - go on
The arguments [k]had been going on[/k] for years so we decided to split up last year.
Past Perfect Continuous - call
Her old boss [k]had been calling[/k] her for weeks to ask her to come back to her job. She didn't know what to do.
Past Perfect Continuous - you stand
[k]Had you been standing[/k] there long when he saw you?
Past Perfect Continuous - not go out
We [k]hadn't been going out|had not been going out[/k] very long and didn't know each other very well.
Grammar: Reported questions
The sentence is a question.
He asked me if I wanted a cup of tea.
What would you like to do this weekend?
She asked me where I was from.
When we are reporting a question that someone asks, the sentence we say is not formed as a question. We usually introduce a reported question with the verb ask.
She asked me what tea I wanted.
He asked me if I had sent the text message.
She asked me whether I was worried about my finances.
We can use if and whether to introduce reported 'yes/no' questions:
He asked me if I had sent the text message. She asked me whether I was worried about my finances.
He asked me how much money I saved each month.
She asked me if I had spoken to them.
She asked me why I had got a loan.
When we report an 'open' question we use the question word in the sentence:
She asked me what I was doing. He asked me how much money I saved each month.
[k]He asked[/k] [k]me[/k] [k]if[/k] [k]I had bought[/k] [k]a new phone.[/k]
[k]She wondered[/k] [k]if[/k] [k]we[/k] [k]were[/k] [k]in debt.[/k]
[k]She asked[/k] [k]if[/k] [k]I[/k] [k]was selling[/k] [k]my phone.[/k]
The verb ask can be used with or without an object:
She asked me if... / She asked if...
The verb wonder is always used without an object:
She wondered if... not* <strike>She wondered me if...</strike>
[k]He asked[/k] [k]me[/k] [k]what[/k] [k]type of phone[/k] [k]I had.[/k]
[k]She wondered[/k] [k]who[/k] [k]the shareholders[/k] [k]were.[/k]
[k]She asked[/k] [k]which[/k] [k]investment bank[/k] [k]we used.[/k]
The clause after the reporting verb is always ordered as a statement, not as a question:

She asked me what I wanted. 
not* <strike>She asked me what did I want.</strike>
She asked [k]me[/k] what [k]I was doing[/k].
to me
was I doing
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
My parents asked me [k]if[/k] I wanted to visit [k]them[/k] for the holidays.
that
him
Our new boss asked [k]him[/k] if [k]he could work[/k] late.
he
could he work
My friend [k]wanted to know[/k] what you were doing tonight[k].[/k]
asking
The waiter is asking [k]if[/k]you want ice in your water.
what
